required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 14, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Dental Anxiety Among Children Pre and Post COVID 19 Pandemic
clinical_study.official_title: Dental Anxiety Among Egyptian Children Pre and Post COVID 19

brief_summary.textblock: Dental fear and anxiety is a significant issue that affects pediatric patients and creates challenges in oral health management. Considering that the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic, along with its associated sanitary regime, social distancing measures and nationwide quarantines, could itself induce public fears, including in children, it is of great interest to explore whether this situation and the necessity of reorganizing dental care could potentially affect the emotional state of pediatric patients facing a need for urgent dental intervention

primary_outcome.time_frame: through study completion, an average of 3 months
primary_outcome.description: Assessment will performed by using Facial image scale (FIS)It consists of 5 faces ranging from very happy to very unhappy. At the beginning, the 5 faces have been explained to all children and they were asked to point to the face which best describes how he/she felt at the moment

study_pop.textblock: children with an age range 4-6 years attending the outpatient clinic of the of Pediatric Dentistry and Dental Public Health Department, Faculty of Dentistry, Alexandria University

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- parental consent
- no previous dental experience
- medically free children
Exclusion Criteria:
- children with negative behavior according to Frankl Rating Scale
- children require general anesthesia

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant lecturer of DPH and Clinical statistician
